title: Korea, U.K. Sign Post-Brexit FTA
text:
Korea and the U.K. signed a free trade agreement on Thursday that will go a small way to propping up Britain if it leaves the EU without a deal.

The two countries wound up their negotiations after two years and eight months, having started them right after the U.K. decided to leave the EU in 2016.

The deal was signed by Trade Minister Yoo Myung-hee and her British counterpart Liz Truss in London, according to the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy here. It consists of essentially the same terms as the Korea-EU FTA.

Korea's main exports like cars and parts can still be shipped to the U.K. without tariffs.

While the U.K. remains in the EU, 99.6 percent of goods exported to the U.K. are benefiting from Korea's tariff-free trade with the EU. But if Brexit had become a reality without a deal, 4.73 percent tariffs could have been imposed on Korean goods.

"The FTA is important because the two countries can maintain continuity and stability of bilateral trade relations even in a no-deal Brexit scenario in which the U.K. unilaterally withdraws from the EU," a ministry spokesman said.
